Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task has generous buffer time and others can proceed without it for a while.
Expectation2: Follow laws and respect others’ rights and public property
Situation2: Late-evening music plans overlap with the building’s quiet hours while a neighbor’s windows are open.
Story: I stared at my laptop, the spreadsheet half-finished, but I knew I had plenty of time before the deadline. My colleagues trusted me to get it done, and honestly, no one was waiting on my part tonight. The real excitement was the music session I’d planned with friends—something we’d been looking forward to all week. We’d agreed to meet in my apartment, and I’d promised to bring my guitar. But as I set up the speakers, I remembered the building’s quiet hours started at 10 p.m. I glanced out the window and saw my neighbor, Mrs. Lee, enjoying the cool air with her windows wide open. As a citizen, I knew I should respect the rules and her right to peace. But as a colleague, I felt a pull to unwind and recharge, so I could be productive tomorrow. The music would help me relax, but it might disturb her. My mind spun with the weight of both roles, each expectation tugging at me, and I stood frozen, guitar in hand, caught between the urge to let loose and the responsibility to be considerate.
